perturbation.original_text: NetGrocer will make these Click-through payments (if any) to Excite within thirty (30) days of Excite's monthly report and invoice reflecting Click-throughs during the first year of the term of the Agreement in excess of [*]
perturbation.changed_text: NetGrocer will make these Click-through payments (if any) to Excite within sixty (60) days of Excite's monthly report and invoice reflecting Click-throughs during the first year of the term of the Agreement in excess of [*]
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that NetGrocer will make Click-through payments within thirty (30) days of Excite's monthly report and invoice. Extending this payment window to sixty (60) days may not comply with California's Prompt Payment Laws, where disputes exist. While not a direct violation, extending the payment period significantly increases the risk of violating implied duties of good faith and fair dealing, especially if NetGrocer consistently delays payments close to the 60-day mark, effectively pushing the payment terms beyond what is commercially reasonable. Given the contract is governed by California Law, this creates a potential legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duties of good faith and fair dealing under California contract law, potentially conflicting with reasonable commercial practices for payment terms.

perturbation.original_text: All payments that would be due pursuant to Sections 5(b) - (d) up to the date of any termination or expiration of this Agreement will be payable in full within thirty (30) days following such termination or expiration.
perturbation.changed_text: All payments that would be due pursuant to Sections 5(b) - (d) up to the date of any termination or expiration of this Agreement will be payable in full within ninety (90) days following such termination or expiration.
perturbation.explanation: According to California Labor Code Section 201, when an employer discharges an employee, the employee's wages earned and unpaid at the time of discharge are due and payable immediately. Section 202 dictates that an employee who quits must be paid all wages due within 72 hours, unless they provided 72 hours of notice, in which case they are due at the time of quitting. Even in the context of a business-to-business agreement like this one, extending the final payment deadline to ninety (90) days introduces a contradiction, as it creates a significant delay that conflicts with statutory requirements for prompt wage payment. Given that the contract is governed by California law, this could be challenged as an attempt to circumvent labor law protections.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202 regarding prompt payment of wages upon termination or resignation of employment.

perturbation.original_text: Any notice under this Agreement will be in writing and delivered by personal delivery, express courier, confirmed facsimile, confirmed email or certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, and will be deemed given upon personal delivery, one (1) day after deposit with express courier, upon confirmation of receipt of facsimile or email or five (5) days after deposit in the mail.
perturbation.changed_text: Any notice under this Agreement will be in writing and delivered by standard mail, and will be deemed given ten (10) days after deposit in the mail.
perturbation.explanation: California law requires specific methods for serving legal notices, especially in contractual contexts where time is of the essence. Reducing the acceptable methods of notice to standard mail only, and extending the deemed delivery time to ten (10) days, creates a potential contradiction. This is because certain critical actions may require faster notification methods. For example, imagine a scenario where the agreement allows termination for breach, and the breach needs to be cured within 30 days of notice. If notice is only sent via standard mail, and is deemed received ten days later, the breaching party effectively has only 20 days to cure the breach. This can create a legal challenge if it contradicts industry standards or implied duties of reasonable notice, especially if a method is chosen to deliberately extend the notice timeline.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with California legal standards requiring reasonable methods of notice, especially in situations where time is of the essence.
